title: Phish or Legit? - Identify the Threat
question: Is this phishing or legit?

stories.scenario: You receive an email from your bank saying your account has been temporarily suspended. It asks you to click a link and confirm your login details immediately.
options: Phishing – suspicious link and urgent request
stories.explanation: Banks usually do not ask to confirm login via email. Urgency and unknown links are typical phishing signs.

stories.scenario: You get a message from your manager asking you to download a document from a Google Drive link. The sender's email looks slightly off: manager@companny.com
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: The misspelled domain and unexpected link indicate a phishing attempt.

stories.scenario: An SMS says you won a gift card and provides a link to claim it. You don't remember entering any contest.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: Unsolicited prizes are common phishing tactics; avoid clicking links from unknown sources.

stories.scenario: You receive an email from your HR department with your payslip attached in PDF. The email comes from hr@company.com as usual.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: The email is from a verified source with expected content; this is likely safe.

stories.scenario: A pop-up on a website says your computer is infected and asks to download an 'antivirus tool' immediately.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: Unexpected pop-ups asking to download software are usually scams.

stories.scenario: You receive an email from a coworker asking for help with a project. The tone is slightly off, and it asks you to open a ZIP file.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: Unexpected attachments, even from coworkers, can be phishing if the tone or request is unusual.

stories.scenario: An online store emails you a receipt for a purchase you made yesterday. Everything looks normal, and links point to the store domain.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: The email matches your recent activity and comes from a trusted domain.

stories.scenario: You receive a LinkedIn message from someone you don't know offering a job opportunity. They ask you to submit personal info via a link.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
options: Phishing – unknown sender and info request
stories.explanation: Unexpected requests for personal information from unknown contacts are classic phishing.

stories.scenario: Your antivirus software notifies you about an outdated version and prompts an automatic update through the program itself.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: Official software update prompts from trusted programs are safe; avoid third-party pop-ups.

stories.scenario: You get an email from a friend asking to check a funny video link. The link shortener is unknown and redirects outside social media platforms.
stories.question: Phish or Legit?
stories.explanation: Shortened or unknown links can hide malicious sites, even if sent by friends; verify before clicking.

tips.title: What should you pay attention to?
info: Read the stories carefully. Look for some suspicious elements. Decide if the story is phishing or legit.
Not all stories are phishing, some are perfectly safe.
Look for common phishing signs: urgent requests, unknown links, misspelled domains, unexpected attachments, unsolicited prizes, and requests for personal info.
